paper_title.ja: Effects Endurance Training on Lactate Threshold and Plasma K+ Concentration in Hypokalemic Rats :
paper_title.en: Effects of endurance training on lactate threshold and plasma K<sup>+</sup> concentration in hypokalemic rats.

description.ja: NAGAOKA, R.NURUKI, A.UCHIDA, S.YUNOKUCHI, K.and AKAIKE, N., Effects of Endurance Training on Lactate Threshold and Plasma K^+ Concentration in Hypokalemic Rats.Adv.Exerc.Sports Physiol., Vol.5, No.4 pp.101-104, 1999. The effects of endurance training and non-training were investigated in hypokalemic rats fed a K^+ -deficient diet with deionized water. The hypokalemia-training rat group was loaded a treadmill running at 12 m/min for 30 minutes, 3 times/week. Blood sample for lactate measurement was collected by cannulating into right atrium from external juglar vein. The running distance, plasma K^+ concentration and lactate threshold were significantly greater in trained hypokalemic rats about 6 weeks than in untrained hypokalemic ones. There was a tendency that hypokalemia-training rats keep the life longer than the untrained hypokalemic ones. These results indicate that endurance training of hypokalemic rats based on aerobic exercise could delay the progress of hypokalemia.
description.en: NAGAOKA, R.NURUKI, A.UCHIDA, S.YUNOKUCHI, K.and AKAIKE, N., Effects of Endurance Training on Lactate Threshold and Plasma K^+ Concentration in Hypokalemic Rats.Adv.Exerc.Sports Physiol., Vol.5, No.4 pp.101-104, 1999. The effects of endurance training and non-training were investigated in hypokalemic rats fed a K^+ -deficient diet with deionized water. The hypokalemia-training rat group was loaded a treadmill running at 12 m/min for 30 minutes, 3 times/week. Blood sample for lactate measurement was collected by cannulating into right atrium from external juglar vein. The running distance, plasma K^+ concentration and lactate threshold were significantly greater in trained hypokalemic rats about 6 weeks than in untrained hypokalemic ones. There was a tendency that hypokalemia-training rats keep the life longer than the untrained hypokalemic ones. These results indicate that endurance training of hypokalemic rats based on aerobic exercise could delay the progress of hypokalemia.

paper_title.en: CHANGES OF INTRACELLULAR ELECTROLYTE CONTENTS IN RAT SKELETAL-MUSCLE DURING BODY SUSPENSION

description.en: The CNS-mediated inhibition of active Na+-K+ transport in both ''type S'' muscle, soleus (SOL), and ''type FF'' muscle, extensor digitorum longus (EDL) was investigated in rats suspended horizontally. Plasma Na+ and K+ contents did not change during the suspension period. The relative wet weight of SOL decreased more than that of EDL by suspension. There was significant intracellular Na+ accumulation and K+ loss in both SOL and diaphragm of suspended rats. However, cerebrum, cerebellum, medulla oblongate, ventricle, liver, pancreas, kidney, intestine, aorta and EDL were spared from the intracellular Na+ accumulation and K+ loss. Sciatic nerve sectioning or cervical spinal cord transection recovered the Na+ and K+ contents in the SOL of suspended rats. The results indicate the existence of neural inhibition of the active Na+-K+ transport in skeletal muscle of the suspended rats.
